```{r data generation, echo = FALSE, results = "hide"}
library(latex2exp)
options(scipen=999)
while(T){
  xbar = signif(runif(1,30,120),3)
  sig = signif(runif(1,xbar/10,xbar/3),2)
  ell = runif(1,0.8,0.99)
  n = sample(c(30,50,10,300,500,1000,3000,5000),1)
  z = qnorm(ell)
  ME = signif(z*sig/sqrt(n),1)
  gam = round(2*ell-1,2)
  z = round(qnorm((gam+1)/2),2)
  n = (z*sig/ME)^2
  n2 = ceiling(n)
  mag = ceiling(log(n)/log(10))
  n3 = ceiling(n/10^(mag-2))*10^(mag-2)
  if(T){
    break
  }
}
```

Question
========

A researcher hopes to characterize the average time on social media spent by BHCC students with a `r gam*100`% confidence interval. Somehow the researcher knows the standard deviation is `r sig` minutes. How large of a sample is needed to to get the margin of error down to `r ME` minutes?

Solution
========

We are given the population standard deviation, confidence level, and margin of error.
$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma &= `r sig`\\
\gamma &= `r gam`\\
ME &= `r ME`
\end{aligned}
$$

Determine the critical $z$ value, $z^\star$, such that $P(|Z|<z^\star) = `r gam`$. Remember, $\ell = \frac{\gamma+1}{2} = \frac{`r gam`+1}{2} = `r (gam+1)/2`$
$$z^\star = `r z` $$
Use the formula for sample size.
$$\begin{aligned}
n &= \left(\frac{z^\star \sigma}{ME} \right)^2 \\\\
&= \left(\frac{(`r z`)(`r sig`)}{`r ME`}\right)^2 \\\\
&= `r n`
\end{aligned}$$
Round up.
$$n = `r n2` $$
